answer: <p>You should use <a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#equals(java.lang.Object)" rel="noreferrer">string equals</a> to compare two strings for equality, not operator == which just compares the references.</p>

<p>Generally <code>.equals</code> is used for <code>Object</code> comparison, where you want to verify if two <code>Objects</code> have an identical value.</p>

<p><code>==</code> for reference comparison (are the two <code>Objects</code> the same <code>Object</code> on the heap) &amp; to check if the <code>Object</code> is null. It is also used to compare the values of primitive types.</p>

<p>The == operator is a simple comparison of values.<br>
For object references the (values) are the (references). So x == y returns true if x and y reference the same object.</p>

<p>The <code>.equals()</code> will check if the two strings have the same value and return the <code>boolean</code> value where as the <code>==</code> operator checks to see if the two strings are the same object.</p>
data.title: String.equals versus == [duplicate]
